title: 109_hr1047
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Pentagon 9/11 Memorial Commemorative Coin Act of 2005". The Congress finds that construction of the Pentagon was completed on January 15, 1943, and a memorial for the victims of the September 11, 2001 attack is to be built on the western side of the Pentagon Building by late fall 2006, requiring almost $30,000,000 in private sector funding. The surcharge proceeds from the sale of a commemorative coin would raise funding for the construction and maintenance of the Pentagon Memorial in remembrance of those who lost their lives on September 11, 2001. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $50 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $50 gold coins with specific weights and diameters as outlined in the specifications for half dollar coins in the United States Code. The number of gold coins minted will be determined by adding 10,000 to the number of innocent individuals confirmed or presumed to have been killed in the 9/11 Pentagon terrorist attack. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary can only use metals from natural deposits in the US or its territories. Congress acknowledges the effectiveness of certain limitations in the US Code. The Act aims to stabilize markets for commemorative coins, maximize demand, ensure broad private support, and prevent fundraising misuse. The significance of September 11, 2001, justifies exempting limitations for the Pentagon Memorial Fund coin program. The Act aims to stabilize markets for commemorative coins and maximize demand. The limitations in certain paragraphs are justified to exempt coins produced under this Act. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the courage of those involved in the Pentagon and Flight 77 on September 11, 2001. The coins will feature a value designation, the year 2001, and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with various entities. The design of the coins minted under this Act will symbolize the courage of those involved in the Pentagon and Flight 77 on September 11, 2001. The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Memorial Fund, Commission of Fine Arts, and Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. The issuance of coins under this Act will symbolize the courage of those involved in the Pentagon and Flight 77 on September 11, 2001. The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with relevant committees. The coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated quality, except for $50 gold coins which will be issued in proof quality. Only one facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike a particular quality of coins, except for half dollar coins which can be struck at any number of facilities. The Secretary will start issuing coins soon after the enactment of the Act and will stop issuing them after one year. The coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated quality, except for $50 gold coins which will be issued in proof quality. The Secretary will start issuing coins soon after the enactment of the Act and will stop issuing them after one year. No coins will be issued after the 1-year period from the initial issuance date. The Act authorizes the sale of coins in uncirculated quality, with $50 gold coins issued in proof quality. The Secretary will begin issuing coins shortly after the Act is enacted and will cease issuance after one year. No coins will be issued after the 1-year period from the initial issuance date. The Act authorizes the sale of coins at a price including face value, surcharges, and design costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with reasonable discounts. The Act authorizes the sale of coins at a price including face value, surcharges, and design costs. Prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. Additionally, gold coins will be issued free of charge to the next of kin or personal representative of identified individuals. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES ON SALE OF COINS.

Any sale of coins minted under this Act includes surcharges: $100 for $50 gold coins, $10 for $1 coins, and $5 for half dollar coins. Surcharges go to the Pentagon Memorial Fund for memorial construction. The Fund is audited for amounts received.
